column1: Quote
"Man must rise above the Earth—to the top of the atmosphere and beyond—for only thus will he fully understand the world in which he lives."
"Astronomy compels the soul to look upward, and leads us from this world to another."
"The purpose of life is the investigation of the Sun, the Moon, and the heavens."

"Mortal as I am, I know that I am born for a day, but when I follow the serried multitude of the stars in their circular course, my feet no longer touch the earth; I ascend to Zeus himself to feast me on ambrosia, the food of the gods."

"The strongest affection and utmost zeal should, I think, promote the studies concerned with the most beautiful objects. This is the discipline that deals with the universe's divine revolutions, the stars' motions, sizes, distances, risings and settings . . . for what is more beautiful than heaven?"

"Astronomy is useful because it raises us above ourselves; it is useful because it is grand; …. It shows us how small is man's body, how great his mind, since his intelligence can embrace the whole of this dazzling immensity, where his body is only an obscure point, and enjoy its silent harmony."
"Do not look at stars as bright spots only. Try to take in the vastness of the universe."
"I am just learning to notice the different colors of the stars, and already begin to have a new enjoyment."
"Astronomy taught us our insignificance in Nature."
"Astronomers, like burglars and jazz musicians, operate best at night."
"For my confirmation, I didn't get a watch and my first pair of long pants, like most Lutheran boys. I got a telescope. My mother thought it would make the best gift."
"Equipped with his five senses, man explores the universe around him and calls the adventure Science."
"I'm sure the universe is full of intelligent life. It's just been too intelligent to come here."

"The cosmos is all that is or ever was or ever will be. Our feeblest contemplations of the Cosmos stir us—there is a tingling in the spine, a catch in the voice, a faint sensation, as if a distant memory, or falling from a height. We know we are approaching the greatest of mysteries."
"If it’s a new planet, sign me up. I’m tired of driving around the block, boldly going where hundreds have gone before in orbit around earth—give me a place to go and I’ll go."
"To confine our attention to terrestrial matters would be to limit the human spirit."
"Space isn't remote at all. It's only an hour's drive away, if your car could go straight upwards."
"Space is for everybody. It's not just for a few people in science or math, or for a select group of astronauts. That's our new frontier out there, and it's everybody's business to know about space."
"We especially need imagination in science. It is not all mathematics, nor all logic, but it is somewhat beauty and poetry."
"Every formula which expresses a law of nature is a hymn of praise to God."
"There will come with the greater love of science greater love to one another."
"The universe is made of stories, not of atoms."
"Follow your bliss and the universe will open doors where there were only walls."
"Science without religion is lame; religion without science is blind."
"The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the source of all true art and science."
"All our science, measured against reality, is primitive and childlike — and yet it is the most precious thing we have."
"The greatest scientists are artists as well."
"All of science is nothing more than the refinement of everyday thinking."
"The stars arise, and the night is holy."
"And in the end we are nothing more than love and space dust."
"The reward of the young scientist is the emotional thrill of being the first person in the history of the world to see something or to understand something."
The truth will prevail in the end. Nonsense will fall of its own weight, by a sort of intellectual law of gravitation.
"Astronomy compels the soul to look upwards and leads us from this world to another."
"The skies are painted with unnumber’d sparks."
"In the beginning the Universe was created. This has made a lot of people very angry and has been widely regarded as a bad move."
"When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to everything else in the universe."
"It is always sunrise somewhere."
"Real knowledge is to know the extent of one’s ignorance."
"The universe is full of magical things patiently waiting for our wits to grow sharper."
"Bright points in the sky or a blow on the head will equally cause one to see stars."
"Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge."
"Imagination will often carry us to worlds that never were. But without it we go nowhere."
"Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious."
"We’re made of star-stuff. We are a way for the cosmos to know itself."
"Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence."
"The universe is not required to be in perfect harmony with human ambition."
"For me, it is far better to grasp the Universe as it really is than to persist in delusion."
"There is no problem in science that can be solved by a man that cannot be solved by a woman."
"We have peered into a new world and have seen that it is more mysterious and more complex than we had imagined."
"Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence."
"Hitch your wagon to a star."
"We are just an advanced breed of monkeys on a minor planet of a very average star. But we can understand the Universe."
"Science is not only a disciple of reason, but, also, one of romance and passion. "
"Try to make sense of what you see and wonder about what makes the universe exist. Be curious."
"Light brings us news of the Universe."
"Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood. "
"In questions of science, the authority of a thousand is not worth the humble reasoning of a single individual."
"The universe begins to look more and more like a great thought than like a great machine."
"One voice, speaking truth is a greater force than fleets and armies."
"Doubt is the origin of wisdom."
"Excuse me while I kiss the sky."
"You are the vast thing that you see far, far off with the great telescopes."
"Everything changes the moment the stars come out."
"It often seems to me that the night is even more richly colored than the day."
"The sight of the stars always makes me dream."
"The stars sing an anthem of glory I cannot put into speech."
"I have loved the stars too fondly to be fearful of the night."
"We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars."
"You wanna read poetry, look at the stars."
"Come quickly, I am tasting the stars!"
"The universe is one of God’s thoughts."
"I don’t feel frightened by not knowing things, by being lost in the mysterious universe."
"There are more things in heaven and Earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy."
"My own suspicion is that the Universe is not only queerer than we suppose, but queerer than we can suppose."
"What is it that breathes fire into the equations and makes a universe for them to govern?"
"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable. But there it sits, nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
"I wheeled with the stars, my heart broke loose on the wind. "

"There is a theory which states that if ever anyone discovers exactly what the Universe is for and why it is here, it will instantly disappear and be replaced by something even more bizarre and inexplicable. There is another theory which states that this has already happened. "
"From time immemorial travel and discovery have called with strange insistence to him who, wondering on the world, felt adventure in his veins."

"Star light, star bright,
First star I see tonight,
I wish I may, I wish I might,
Have this wish I wish tonight."
"Two possibilities exist: Either we are alone in the Universe or we are not. Both are equally terrifying."

"Fly me to the moon
Let me play among the stars
Let me see what spring is like
On Jupiter and Mars"
"…for when I finish my other work I can spend all night sweeping the heavens. "
"The purpose of this life is the investigation of the sun, the moon, and the heavens."
"The cosmos is all that is, or ever was, or ever will be. "

"We shall not cease from exploration
And the end of all our exploring
Will be to arrive where we started 
And know the place for the first time. "

"When he shall die,
Take him and cut him out in little stars,
And he will make the face of heaven so fine
That all the world will be in love with night."
“Man must rise above the Earth—to the top of the atmosphere and beyond—for only thus will he fully understand the world in which he lives.”

“To set foot on the soil of the asteroids, to lift by hand a rock from the Moon, to observe Mars from a distance of several tens of kilometers, to land on its satellite or even on its surface, what can be more fantastic? From the moment of using rocket devices a new great era will begin in astronomy: the epoch of the more intensive study of the firmament. “

“Astronomy is useful because it raises us above ourselves; it is useful because it is grand… It shows us how small is man’s body, how great his mind, since his intelligence can embrace the whole of this dazzling immensity, where his body is only an obscure point, and enjoy its silent harmony.”
“Cosmology brings us face to face with the deepest mysteries, questions that were once treated only in religion and myth.”

“Cosmology is peculiar among the sciences for it is both the oldest and the youngest. From the dawn of civilization man has speculated about the nature of the starry heavens and the origin of the world, but only in the present century has physical cosmology split away from general philosophy to become an independent discipline.”
“Cosmology is a science which has only a few observable facts to work with.”
“The universe is like a safe to which there is a combination, but the combination is locked up in the safe.”
"Astronomy is perhaps the science whose discoveries owe least to chance, in which human understanding appears in its whole magnitude, and through which man can best learn how small he is.”
“There is in the universe neither center nor circumference.”
"The history of astronomy is a history of receding horizons.”

“General space — that sea of ether which has no shores, and stretches on, and on, and arrives nowhere; which is a waste of black gloom and thick darkness through which you may rush forever at thought-speed, encountering at weary long intervals spirit-cheering archipelagoes of suns which rise sparkling far in front of you, and swiftly grow and swell, and burst into blinding glories of light, apparently measureless in extent, but you plung through and in a moment they are far behind, a twinkling archipelago again, and in another moment they are blotted out in darkness; constellations, these? yes; and the earliest of them the property of your own solar system; the rest of that unending flight is through solar systems not known to men.”
